Classes for defining a chemical reaction system.

Exports:

Rxn: A chemical reaction RevRxn: A reversible chemical reaction RxnSystem: A collection of reactions and conditions (e.g. initial

concentrations).

Usage:

Usage essentially always looks like the following, where you make a reaction system with other classes as inputs.

RxnSystem(

sm,

Rxn(x, y, k=3.2), RevRxn(x + y, 2z, k1=0.01, k2=100),

Conc(x, 2), …

)

It looks like this because it was made to imitate the predecessor mathematica project.

class lblcrn.crn_sym.reaction.RevRxn(reactants: Optional[sympy.core.expr.Expr], products: Optional[sympy.core.expr.Expr], k: float, k2: float = None)¶

A reversible reaction, essentially a reaction with two rate constants.

Its use is to be quickly unpacked into two Rxns.

as_dict() → dict¶

Return a MSON-serializable dict representation.

get_symbols() → Set[sympy.core.symbol.Symbol]¶
to_rxns() → Tuple[lblcrn.crn_sym.reaction.Rxn, lblcrn.crn_sym.reaction.Rxn]¶
to_terms() → List[lblcrn.crn_sym.conditions.Term]¶

Create a list of terms from the reaction.

Each term is essentially the reaction rate but positive or negative, depending on if it is a reactand or the product.

This uses the reaction rate formula r = k*(concentration of products^coefficient of product): if this is false for your chemical equation, you will get an error.

class lblcrn.crn_sym.reaction.Rxn(reactants: Optional[sympy.core.expr.Expr], products: Optional[sympy.core.expr.Expr], k: float)¶

A chemical reaction with reactants, products, and a rate constant.

reactants¶

A sym.Expr of the reactants.

products¶

A sym.Expr of the products.

rate_constant¶

A float, the rate constant of the chemical reaction.

as_dict() → dict¶

Return a MSON-serializable dict representation.

classmethod from_dict(d: dict)¶

Load from a dict representation.

get_symbols() → Set[sympy.core.symbol.Symbol]¶
to_terms() → List[lblcrn.crn_sym.conditions.Term]¶

Create a list of terms from the reaction.

Each term is essentially the reaction rate but positive or negative, depending on if it is a reactand or the product.

This uses the reaction rate formula r = k*(concentration of products^coefficient of product): if this is false for your chemical equation, you will get an error.

class lblcrn.crn_sym.reaction.RxnSystem(*components)¶

A chemical reaction system, for simulation.

A collection of Terms, Rxns, Schedules, etc. which describes a chemical reaction system for the purpose of simulating it (namely the concentrations of each chemical) over time.

components¶

Everything the RxnSystem contains

terms¶

Terms in the ODE of the system.

schedules¶

The Schedules and Concs passed during initialization.

conc_eqs¶

The ConcEqs in the system.

conc_diffeqs¶

The ConcDiffEqs in the system.

species_manager¶

The SpeciesManager the system uses.

symbol_index¶

A dictionary {sym.Symbol: int} to keep track of the order of the symbols.

scheduler¶

A comprehensive Schedule of the system, has entries (which might be Conc(species, 0) for each species which isn’t set by a ConcEq.

as_dict() → dict¶

Return a MSON-serializable dict representation.

classmethod from_dict(d: dict)¶

Load from a dict representation.

get_conc_functions()¶

Return the functions corresponding to the ConcEqs.

Used internally by get_ode_functions.

get_ode_expressions() → List[sympy.core.expr.Expr]¶

Return a list of expressions, corresponding to the derivative of the concentration of each symbol in the reaction system.

The collection is ordered, and that order is accessible through symbol_index or through get_symbols.

get_ode_functions()¶

Return the ODE function with signature func(t, y) of the system.

get_species() → List[lblcrn.crn_sym.species.Species]¶
get_symbols() → List[sympy.core.symbol.Symbol]¶

Give all the symbols in the reaction system in a fixed order.
